fund for faculty-student interactions became available for
general use at Hopkins. This

students and instructors.

guidelines of the fund, faculty

for the cost. Each faculty

the fund once per semester.

'85 MSE Symposium
To Have 5 Speakers
by Frank Capri°
A tentative schedule has been
announced for next fall's
Milton S. Eisenhower Symposium, the lecture series which
has been an annual event at
Hopkins for over fifteen years.
This year the symposium will
address the topic Arms Control: Strategy and Diplomacy
and will undergo a change in
format, which will allow for
more speakers than usual.
The symposium will present
an historical approach to the
diplomatic aspects of the
weapons race while juxtaposing
past policies with those of today. Junior Mike DeRosa and
sophomore Brad Marks, the
undergraduate chairmen of the

1985 symposium, believe that
this approach will be much
more interesting than simply
having individual lectures on
certain issues such as "Star
Wars" or treaty verifiability.
DeRosa and Marks have set
an ambitious goal of getting
five speakers instead of the
usual three for this year's symposium. While conducting their
search for speakers, they looked for well-known figures from
different periods in U.S.-Soviet
relations so that an overall
perspective could be obtained.
All five speakers now under
consideration have had experience working directly with
the Soviets.

Lack of Initiative
To the Editor:
A significant concern of mine
is the lack of initiative on the
part of the University to see
that undergraduate life is a
pleasant one. By this, I mean
that student amenities are inadequate for a school of this
stature. While amenities
themselves are a big problem
here, of even more concern is
the lack of an expressed interest
in non-classroom life by the administration and the improper
funding of student activities
which is highly disproportionate to the efforts which involved students put into campus life.
While it is true that the
University funds some important, and in my mind, requisite
features of undergraduate life

like Orientation, the SAC,and
the Tutorial, there are other
elements outside of class-life
which tend to slip by the school
budget or which receive
minimal allocation. For instance, it seems irrational for
the administration not to fund
the Course Guide, which is entirely produced for students by
students. Rather, the SAC,
which gets an annual budget
from the school, must fund this
essential publication. Because
the SAC must fund the gamut
of clubs, organizations, and the
like, it is particularly unfair for
student activities money to be
used to support a publication
solely dedicated to education.
Similarly, the Student Council
Career Advising Guide to Internships, which was funded
entirely by the Council, should
be paid for by the administration. Both the Course Guide
and Internship Guide should be
funded by the University
because both are concerned
with educational pursuits.
While funding is a major
problem, perhaps even more
disturbing is the lack of initiative on the part of the
University to do anything
significant in the way of improving student life. I do not
intent to slander those who
work in the SAC office by any
means, but such things as a
housing booklet and a security
manual should be initiated by
the administration, not by the
Student Council. While Council has a responsibility to represent the student body and pur-

sue salient issues, it and SAC
groups cannot be expected to,
nor should have to, initiate,
produce, and fund nearly all of
the important undergraduate
publications, organizations, or
special projects. The administration, and by this I particularly mean the Deans, must
realize that student obligations,
at least of those who are actively involved on campus in areas
other than just the classroom,
are greatly stretched. For
Spring Fair to be student initiated and run is wonderful,
but should the same be said for
security measures like quad
monitors and security phones?
A line must be drawn between
what is fun, interesting, and
beneficial to the community
and what is necessary,
obligatory, or essential to the
students on this campus. The
former should remain funded
and organized as is, but the latter must be assumed by the
administration.
I am among those who extol
and expect student involvement. Perhaps my best education has come from my "nonacademic" activities and the
people with whom I have worked. However, I abhor the fact
that too much is undertaken by
students because students
perceive the need for a certain
policy to be addressed, like
security or course evaluation,
when it is the responsibility of
the University to see that such
matters are handled under its
auspices.
It is time for the school to

wake up to the fact that
students want more than an
education in the traditional
sense. It is time to realize that
portions of tuition should be
directed towards students
amenities, and more importantly, to student necessities. A
good caveat is this: those
among the undergraduates who
are dedicated to student life are
few, and while they are involved now, the possibility of equally dedicated and concerned individuals in coming years is, at
best, uncertain. To avoid
potential problems with student
apathy and student necessities,
the administration must exercise geater interest and involvement in undergraduate life—
beginning now!
Sincerely,
Joff Masukawa

From Off Campus
To the Editor:
I am writing this letter in
hopes that I might alert my
fellow college students and the
public at large to the budget
proposals concerning federal
student aid funds. I realize that
these may not affect everyone
who is reading this, but it will
affect about half of all college
students and their families.
The President has proposed
a flat limit of $4000 on federal
tuition aid to any one person
for 1986. This may sound like
a lot, but considering that college can costs upwards of
$15,000 per year, it is a mere

drop in the bucket for some.
Also proposed are income ceilings for eligibility which would
prevent many current recipients
from obtaining grants and
guaranteed student loans. It
will be argued, though, that not
everyone has the right to go to
Harvard or Yale (which both
provide excellent financial aid
of their own)or any one of the
more prestigious universities in
this country. This is true for
academic merit, but why should
someone be deprived of attending the school he will be happiest in or that will best suit
him, or for that matter, any
college at all, because of financial poverty? Just because a
person cannot afford a particular college doesn't mean
that he would not become a
valuable part of that college's
student body or of society.
In the past few years, Congress has not accepted the first
proposals for students aid cuts,
but to ensure that everyone retains the right to attend college,
I would suggest that everyone
who reads this letter and holds
the same views, cut it out and
mail it, or a letter of their own,
to President Reagan or their
respective Congessman. It may
not provoke any radical
changes in the opinions of our
leaders, but it will surely alert
them to the fact that there are
people who are concerned and
disagree.
David L. Peter
Washington & Lee University
Lexington, Virginia

Lack of Initiative
To the Editor:
A significant concern of mine
is the lack of initiative on the
part of the University to see
that undergraduate life is a
pleasant one. By this, I mean
that student amenities are inadequate for a school of this
stature. While amenities
themselves are a big problem
here, of even more concern is
the lack of an expressed interest
in non-classroom life by the administration and the improper
funding of student activities
which is highly disproportionate to the efforts which involved students put into campus life.
While it is true that the
University funds some important, and in my mind, requisite
features of undergraduate life

like Orientation, the SAC,and
the Tutorial, there are other
elements outside of class-life
which tend to slip by the school
budget or which receive
minimal allocation. For instance, it seems irrational for
the administration not to fund
the Course Guide, which is entirely produced for students by
students. Rather, the SAC,
which gets an annual budget
from the school, must fund this
essential publication. Because
the SAC must fund the gamut
of clubs, organizations, and the
like, it is particularly unfair for
student activities money to be
used to support a publication
solely dedicated to education.
Similarly, the Student Council
Career Advising Guide to Internships, which was funded
entirely by the Council, should
be paid for by the administration. Both the Course Guide
and Internship Guide should be
funded by the University
because both are concerned
with educational pursuits.
While funding is a major
problem, perhaps even more
disturbing is the lack of initiative on the part of the
University to do anything
significant in the way of improving student life. I do not
intent to slander those who
work in the SAC office by any
means, but such things as a
housing booklet and a security
manual should be initiated by
the administration, not by the
Student Council. While Council has a responsibility to represent the student body and pur-

sue salient issues, it and SAC
groups cannot be expected to,
nor should have to, initiate,
produce, and fund nearly all of
the important undergraduate
publications, organizations, or
special projects. The administration, and by this I particularly mean the Deans, must
realize that student obligations,
at least of those who are actively involved on campus in areas
other than just the classroom,
are greatly stretched. For
Spring Fair to be student initiated and run is wonderful,
but should the same be said for
security measures like quad
monitors and security phones?
A line must be drawn between
what is fun, interesting, and
beneficial to the community
and what is necessary,
obligatory, or essential to the
students on this campus. The
former should remain funded
and organized as is, but the latter must be assumed by the
administration.
I am among those who extol
and expect student involvement. Perhaps my best education has come from my "nonacademic" activities and the
people with whom I have worked. However, I abhor the fact
that too much is undertaken by
students because students
perceive the need for a certain
policy to be addressed, like
security or course evaluation,
when it is the responsibility of
the University to see that such
matters are handled under its
auspices.
It is time for the school to

wake up to the fact that
students want more than an
education in the traditional
sense. It is time to realize that
portions of tuition should be
directed towards students
amenities, and more importantly, to student necessities. A
good caveat is this: those
among the undergraduates who
are dedicated to student life are
few, and while they are involved now, the possibility of equally dedicated and concerned individuals in coming years is, at
best, uncertain. To avoid
potential problems with student
apathy and student necessities,
the administration must exercise geater interest and involvement in undergraduate life—
beginning now!
Sincerely,
Joff Masukawa

From Off Campus
To the Editor:
I am writing this letter in
hopes that I might alert my
fellow college students and the
public at large to the budget
proposals concerning federal
student aid funds. I realize that
these may not affect everyone
who is reading this, but it will
affect about half of all college
students and their families.
The President has proposed
a flat limit of $4000 on federal
tuition aid to any one person
for 1986. This may sound like
a lot, but considering that college can costs upwards of
$15,000 per year, it is a mere

drop in the bucket for some.
Also proposed are income ceilings for eligibility which would
prevent many current recipients
from obtaining grants and
guaranteed student loans. It
will be argued, though, that not
everyone has the right to go to
Harvard or Yale (which both
provide excellent financial aid
of their own)or any one of the
more prestigious universities in
this country. This is true for
academic merit, but why should
someone be deprived of attending the school he will be happiest in or that will best suit
him, or for that matter, any
college at all, because of financial poverty? Just because a
person cannot afford a particular college doesn't mean
that he would not become a
valuable part of that college's
student body or of society.
In the past few years, Congress has not accepted the first
proposals for students aid cuts,
but to ensure that everyone retains the right to attend college,
I would suggest that everyone
who reads this letter and holds
the same views, cut it out and
mail it, or a letter of their own,
to President Reagan or their
respective Congessman. It may
not provoke any radical
changes in the opinions of our
leaders, but it will surely alert
them to the fact that there are
people who are concerned and
disagree.
David L. Peter
Washington & Lee University
Lexington, Virginia

Arnold, and Dave Psenicksa.

yield a run.
